content: The Flood Mitigation Expense Relief Act of 2013, also known as the "Flood Mitigation Expense Relief Act," introduces a credit for qualified flood mitigation expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Flood Mitigation Expense Relief Act of 2013 allows a tax credit for qualified taxpayers equal to flood mitigation expenses paid, not exceeding $5,000. A qualified taxpayer holds flood insurance under the National Flood Insurance Program and owns covered property. The Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 addresses flood insurance coverage and premium rates based on estimated risk premiums for properties in specific areas. The Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 adjusts risk premium rates based on elevation and flood risk designations for properties in certain areas. The Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 adjusts risk premium rates based on flood risk designations. Business employers must be small to qualify for certain tax benefits. Flood mitigation expenses' meaning is determined by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Partnership, S Corporations, and other pass-thru entities have credit and limitations determined at the entity level. The business credit is treated as part of the general business credit, and personal credit is also considered for tax purposes. Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting ``30E(f)(2),'' after ``25A,''. The table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new item. Increased funding for mitigation programs will apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2012. Authorization of Appropriations for mitigation programs: $100,000,000 for predisaster hazard mitigation and $100,000,000 for flood mitigation assistance, to be used for specific activities. The Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 authorizes funding for mitigation activities and property acquisition in areas with revised flood insurance rate maps where properties have lower elevation than the base flood elevation. The Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 applies to properties located in areas with higher flood risk designated after the enactment of the Act. The Energy Star program, run by the US Department of Energy and EPA, is terminated. Any unspent funds for the program are rescinded.
